channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: Secure Your Spot at RSAC 2026 Conference
Black Basta Ransomware Leader Added to EU Most Wanted and INTERPOL Red Notice
item.description: Ukrainian and German law enforcement authorities have identified two Ukrainians suspected of working for the Russia-linked ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) group Black Basta. In addition, the group's alleged leader, a 35-year-old Russian national named Oleg Evgenievich Nefedov (Нефедов Олег Евгеньевич), has been added to the European Union's Most Wanted and INTERPOL's Red Notice lists, authorities
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: OpenAI to Show Ads in ChatGPT for Logged-In U.S. Adults on Free and Go Plans
item.description: OpenAI on Friday said it would start showing ads in ChatGPT to logged-in adult U.S. users in both the free and ChatGPT Go tiers in the coming weeks, as the artificial intelligence (AI) company expanded access to its low-cost subscription globally. "You need to know that your data and conversations are protected and never sold to advertisers," OpenAI said. "And we need to keep a high bar and give
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: More Problems for Fortinet: Critical FortiSIEM Flaw Exploited
item.description: CVE-2025-64155, a command injection vulnerability, was disclosed earlier this week and quickly came under attack from a variety of IP addresses.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: YOLO Mode: Hidden Risks in Claude Code Permissions | UpGuard
item.description: Developers are frequently granting Claude Code permission to download, execute, and delete code, creating fertile ground for prompt injection attacks.

item.title: GootLoader Malware Uses 500–1,000 Concatenated ZIP Archives to Evade Detection
item.description: The JavaScript (aka JScript) malware loader called GootLoader has been observed using a malformed ZIP archive that's designed to sidestep detection efforts by concatenating anywhere from 500 to 1,000 archives. "The actor creates a malformed archive as an anti-analysis technique," Expel security researcher Aaron Walton said in a report shared with The Hacker News. "That is, many unarchiving tools
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CISOs Rise to Prominence: Security Leaders Join the Executive Suite
item.description: Security professionals are moving up the executive ranks as enterprises face rising regulatory and compliance standards.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: Go Programming Language 1.26 Patches Several Security Flaws
item.description: <p>The patched issues span core standard library components including archive/zip and net/http, as well as security-sensitive areas of the crypto/tls stack. </p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-golang-patches-security-flaws/">Go Programming Language 1.26 Patches Several Security Flaws</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: AI and the Corporate Capture of Knowledge
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Five Malicious Chrome Extensions Impersonate Workday and NetSuite to Hijack Accounts
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered five new malicious Google Chrome web browser extensions that masquerade as human resources (HR) and enterprise resource planning (ERP) platforms like Workday, NetSuite, and SuccessFactors to take control of victim accounts. "The extensions work in concert to steal authentication tokens, block incident response capabilities, and enable complete account
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI System Reduces Attack Reconstruction Time From Weeks to Hours
item.description: Pacific Northwest National Labs' expert cybersecurity system, ALOHA, can recreate attacks and test them against organizations' infrastructure to bolster defense.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: TamperedChef Malvertising Campaign Drops Malware via Fake PDF Manuals
item.description: TamperedChef creates backdoors and steals user credentials – particularly in organizations reliant on technical equipment

item.title: Account Compromise Surged 389% in 2025, Says eSentire
item.description: An eSentire report showed credential theft accounted for 74% of all observed cyber threats in 2025

item.title: Your Digital Footprint Can Lead Right to Your Front Door
item.description: You lock your doors at night. You avoid sketchy phone calls. You’re careful about what you post on social media. But what about the information about you that’s already out there—without your permission? Your name. Home address. Phone number. Past jobs. Family members. Old usernames. It’s all still online, and it’s a lot easier to find than you think. The hidden safety threat lurking online Most
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: LOTUSLITE Backdoor Targets U.S. Policy Entities Using Venezuela-Themed Spear Phishing
item.description: Security experts have disclosed details of a new campaign that has targeted U.S. government and policy entities using politically themed lures to deliver a backdoor known as LOTUSLITE. The targeted malware campaign leverages decoys related to the recent geopolitical developments between the U.S. and Venezuela to distribute a ZIP archive ("US now deciding what's next for Venezuela.zip")
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Why LinkedIn is a hunting ground for threat actors – and how to protect yourself
item.description: The business social networking site is a vast, publicly accessible database of corporate information. Don’t believe everyone on the site is who they say they are.

item.title: TikTok to Roll Out Stronger Age Verification Across the EU
item.description: <p>TikTok, and other major platforms popular with young people, are coming under increasing pressure to better identify and remove accounts.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-tiktok-eu-age-verification/">TikTok to Roll Out Stronger Age Verification Across the EU</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: RondoDox Botnet Targets HPE OneView Vulnerability in Exploitation Wave
item.description: Check Point Research has reported a surge in attacks on a vulnerability in HPE OneView, driven by the Linux-based RondoDox botnet

item.title: China-Linked APT Exploited Sitecore Zero-Day in Critical Infrastructure Intrusions
item.description: A threat actor likely aligned with China has been observed targeting critical infrastructure sectors in North America since at least last year. Cisco Talos, which is tracking the activity under the name UAT-8837, assessed it to be a China-nexus advanced persistent threat (APT) actor with medium confidence based on tactical overlaps with other campaigns mounted by threat actors from the region.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Cisco Patches Zero-Day RCE Exploited by China-Linked APT in Secure Email Gateways
item.description: Cisco on Thursday released security updates for a maximum-severity security flaw impacting Cisco AsyncOS Software for Cisco Secure Email Gateway and Cisco Secure Email and Web Manager, nearly a month after the company disclosed that it had been exploited as a zero-day by a China-nexus advanced persistent threat (APT) actor codenamed UAT-9686. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-20393 (CVSS
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Predator Spyware Sample Indicates 'Vendor-Controlled' C2
item.description: Researchers detailed how Intellexa, Predator's owner, uses failed deployments and thwarted infections to strengthen its commercial spyware and generate more effective attacks.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Kaiser to Pay $46M in Patient Data Lawsuit. Find Out If You’re Eligible
item.description: <p>Kaiser Permanente agreed to a $46M settlement over claims that patient health information was improperly disclosed online. The claims deadline is March 12, 2026.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-kaiser-46m-settlement-alleged-patient-data-leak/">Kaiser to Pay $46M in Patient Data Lawsuit. Find Out If You’re Eligible</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Liz Ticong

item.title: CISA Issues New AI Security Guidance for Critical Infrastructure
item.description: <p>CISA and international partners issued new guidance on securing AI in operational technology, warning of OT risks and urging stronger governance and safeguards.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-cisa-ai-security-guidance-2026/">CISA Issues New AI Security Guidance for Critical Infrastructure</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Drew Robb

item.title: AWS CodeBuild Misconfiguration Exposed GitHub Repos to Potential Supply Chain Attacks
item.description: A critical misconfiguration in Amazon Web Services (AWS) CodeBuild could have allowed complete takeover of the cloud service provider's own GitHub repositories, including its AWS JavaScript SDK, putting every AWS environment at risk. The vulnerability has been codenamed CodeBreach by cloud security company Wiz. The issue was fixed by AWS in September 2025 following responsible disclosure on
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Winter Olympics Could Share Podium With Cyberattackers
item.description: The upcoming Winter Games in the Italian Alps are attracting both hacktivists looking to reach billions of people and state-sponsored cyber-spies targeting the attending glitterati.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: PCI SSC Releases Version 2.0 of the PCI Secure Software Standard
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: Global Agencies Release New Guidance to Secure Industrial Networks
item.description: CISA, NCSC and the FBI have released a new security guide to enhance protection for OT environments

item.title: Hackers Increasingly Shun Encryption in Favour of Pure Data Theft and Extortion
item.description: While ‘traditional’ ransomware attacks remain stable, some gangs are shifting towards exploiting zero-days and supply chains to go straight to stealing data

item.title: Critical WordPress Modular DS Plugin Flaw Actively Exploited to Gain Admin Access
item.description: A maximum-severity security flaw in a WordPress plugin called Modular DS has come under active exploitation in the wild, according to Patchstack. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-23550 (CVSS score: 10.0), has been described as a case of unauthenticated privilege escalation impacting all versions of the plugin prior to and including 2.5.1. It has been patched in version 2.5.2. The plugin
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Vulnerabilities Surge, But Messy Reporting Blurs Picture
item.description: MITRE loses its lead as the top reporter of vulnerabilities, while new organizations pump out CVEs and reported bugs in WordPress plug-ins surge.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Researchers Reveal Reprompt Attack Allowing Single-Click Data Exfiltration From Microsoft Copilot
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new attack method dubbed Reprompt that could allow bad actors to exfiltrate sensitive data from artificial intelligence (AI) chatbots like Microsoft Copilot in a single click, while bypassing enterprise security controls entirely. "Only a single click on a legitimate Microsoft link is required to compromise victims," Varonis security
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CodeBuild Flaw Put AWS Console Supply Chain At Risk
item.description: A critical AWS CodeBuild misconfiguration has exposed core repositories to potential attack

item.title: Cyber Threat Actors Ramp Up Attacks on Industrial Environments
item.description: Hacktivists and cybercriminals have intensified their efforts to exploit vulnerabilities in industrial systems, according to a Cyble report

item.title: CISO Role Reaches “Inflexion Point” With Executive-Level Titles
item.description: IANS Research reveals a growth in executive-level CISO titles, amid resource challenges

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: AI Voice Cloning Exploit, Wi-Fi Kill Switch, PLC Vulns, and 14 More Stories
item.description:
The internet never stays quiet. Every week, new hacks, scams, and security problems show up somewhere. This week’s stories show how fast attackers change their tricks, how small mistakes turn into big risks, and how the same old tools keep finding new ways to break in. Read on to catch up before the next wave hits.
Unauthenticated RCE risk
Security Flaw in Redis
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday Fixes 112 Flaws, Includes SharePoint and Windows
item.description: <p>Microsoft’s January 2026 Patch Tuesday fixes 112 CVEs, including an exploited Windows DWM zero-day, plus critical flaws across SharePoint, Office, and Windows services.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-patch-tuesday-january-2026/">Microsoft Patch Tuesday Fixes 112 Flaws, Includes SharePoint and Windows</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Aminu Abdullahi

item.title: Data Privacy Teams Face Staffing Shortages and Budget Constraints, ISACA Warns
item.description: ISACA’s State of Privacy 2026 report reveals that data privacy teams remain understaffed and underfunded, despite growing regulatory demands and rising technical privacy challenges

item.title: New Vulnerability in n8n
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Model Security Is the Wrong Frame – The Real Risk Is Workflow Security
item.description: As AI copilots and assistants become embedded in daily work, security teams are still focused on protecting the models themselves. But recent incidents suggest the bigger risk lies elsewhere: in the workflows that surround those models. Two Chrome extensions posing as AI helpers were recently caught stealing ChatGPT and DeepSeek chat data from over 900,000 users. Separately, researchers
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ICE Agent Doxxing Site DDoS-ed Via Russian Servers
item.description: DDoS-ers are striking a website linked to a data breach at the Department of Homeland Security

item.title: 4 Outdated Habits Destroying Your SOC's MTTR in 2026
item.description: It’s 2026, yet many SOCs are still operating the way they did years ago, using tools and processes designed for a very different threat landscape. Given the growth in volumes and complexity of cyber threats, outdated practices no longer fully support analysts’ needs, staggering investigations and incident response. Below are four limiting habits that may be preventing your SOC from evolving at
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Trio of Critical Bugs Spotted in Delta Industrial PLCs
item.description: Experts disagree on whether the vulnerabilities in a programmable logic controller from Delta are a five-alarm fire or not much to worry over.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Microsoft Legal Action Disrupts RedVDS Cybercrime Infrastructure Used for Online Fraud
item.description: Microsoft on Wednesday announced that it has taken a "coordinated legal action" in the U.S. and the U.K. to disrupt a cybercrime subscription service called RedVDS that has allegedly fueled millions in fraud losses. The effort, per the tech giant, is part of a broader law enforcement effort in collaboration with law enforcement authorities that has allowed it to confiscate the malicious
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Palo Alto Fixes GlobalProtect DoS Flaw That Can Crash Firewalls Without Login
item.description: Palo Alto Networks has released security updates for a high-severity security flaw impacting GlobalProtect Gateway and Portal, for which it said there exists a proof-of-concept (PoC) exploit. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-0227 (CVSS score: 7.7), has been described as a denial-of-service (DoS) condition impacting GlobalProtect PAN-OS software arising as a result of an improper check for
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Retail, Services Industries Under Fire in Oceania
item.description: Last year in Australia, New Zealand, and the South Pacific, Main Street businesses like retail and construction suffered more cyberattacks than their critical sector counterparts.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Hacking Wheelchairs over Bluetooth
item.description: <p>Researchers have <a href="https://www.securityweek.com/researchers-expose-whill-wheelchair-safety-risks-via-remote-hacking/">demonstrated</a> remotely controlling a wheelchair over Bluetooth. CISA has issued an <a href="https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/ics-medical-advisories/icsma-25-364-01">advisory</a>.</p> <blockquote><p>CISA said the WHILL wheelchairs did not enforce authentication for Bluetooth connections, allowing an attacker who is in Bluetooth range of the targeted device to pair with it. The attacker could then control the wheelchair&#8217;s movements, override speed restrictions, and manipulate configuration profiles, all without requiring credentials or user interaction.</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Microsoft Disrupts Cybercrime Service RedVDS
item.description: RedVDS, a cybercrime-as-a-service operation that has stolen millions from victims, lost two domains to a law enforcement operation.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Researchers Null-Route Over 550 Kimwolf and Aisuru Botnet Command Servers
item.description: The Black Lotus Labs team at Lumen Technologies said it null-routed traffic to more than 550 command-and-control (C2) nodes associated with the AISURU/Kimwolf botnet since early October 2025. AISURU and its Android counterpart, Kimwolf, have emerged as some of the biggest botnets in recent times, capable of directing enslaved devices to participate in distributed denial-of-service (DDoS)
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Upcoming Speaking Engagements
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Criminal Subscription Service Behind AI-Powered Cyber-Attacks Taken Out By Microsoft
item.description: RedVDS cyber-crime-as-a-service platform powering phishing, BEC attacks and other fraud has cost victims millions

item.title: Hackers Use Fake PayPal Notices to Steal Credentials, Deploy RMMs
item.description: Phishing attacks have been identified using fake PayPal alerts to exploit remote monitoring and management tools

item.title: 'VoidLink' Malware Poses Advanced Threat to Linux Systems
item.description: Researchers discovered a modular, &quot;cloud-first&quot; framework that is feature-rich and designed to maintain stealthy, long-term access to Linux environments.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: AI Agents Are Becoming Authorization Bypass Paths
item.description: Not long ago, AI agents were harmless. They wrote snippets of code. They answered questions. They helped individuals move a little faster. Then organizations got ambitious. Instead of personal copilots, companies started deploying shared organizational AI agents - agents embedded into HR, IT, engineering, customer support, and operations. Agents that don&rsquo;t just suggest, but act. Agents
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Hackers Exploit c-ares DLL Side-Loading to Bypass Security and Deploy Malware
item.description: Security experts have disclosed details of an active malware campaign that's exploiting a DLL side-loading vulnerability in a legitimate binary associated with the open-source c-ares library to bypass security controls and deliver a wide range of commodity trojans and stealers. "Attackers achieve evasion by pairing a malicious libcares-2.dll with any signed version of the legitimate ahost.exe (
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Leaked Data Exposes Thousands of Border Patrol, ICE Agents After Renee Good Shooting
item.description: <p>A reported DHS leak exposed personal details of about 4,500 ICE and Border Patrol agents after a Minneapolis shooting, raising safety and ethics concerns.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-leaked-data-exposes-thousands-border-patrol-ice-agents/">Leaked Data Exposes Thousands of Border Patrol, ICE Agents After Renee Good Shooting</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Aminu Abdullahi

item.title: Fortinet Fixes Critical FortiSIEM Flaw Allowing Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution
item.description: Fortinet has released updates to fix a critical security flaw impacting FortiSIEM that could allow an unauthenticated attacker to achieve code execution on susceptible instances. The operating system (OS) injection vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-64155, is rated 9.4 out of 10.0 on the CVSS scoring system. "An improper neutralization of special elements used in an OS command ('OS command
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: New Research: 64% of 3rd-Party Applications Access Sensitive Data Without Justification
item.description:
Research analyzing 4,700 leading websites reveals that 64% of third-party applications now access sensitive data without business justification, up from 51% in 2024.&nbsp; Government sector malicious activity spiked from 2% to 12.9%, while 1 in 7 Education sites show active compromise. Specific offenders: Google Tag Manager (8% of violations), Shopify (5%), Facebook Pixel (4%).
Download the
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: UK Digital ID Scheme Faces Resistance Over Security Concerns
item.description: <p>The scheme once appeared inevitable, but that confidence has unraveled amid intense public backlash and troubling security revelations.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-uk-digital-id-scheme-resistance/">UK Digital ID Scheme Faces Resistance Over Security Concerns</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Is it time for internet services to adopt identity verification?
item.description: Should verified identities become the standard online? Australia’s social media ban for under-16s shows why the question matters.

item.title: Microsoft Fixes 114 Windows Flaws in January 2026 Patch, One Actively Exploited
item.description: Microsoft on Tuesday rolled out its first security update for 2026, addressing 114 security flaws, including one vulnerability that it said has been actively exploited in the wild. Of the 114 flaws, eight are rated Critical, and 106 are rated Important in severity. As many as 58 vulnerabilities have been classified as privilege escalation, followed by 22 information disclosure, 21 remote code
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Critical Node.js Vulnerability Can Cause Server Crashes via async_hooks Stack Overflow
item.description: Node.js has released updates to fix what it described as a critical security issue impacting "virtually every production Node.js app" that, if successfully exploited, could trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition. "Node.js/V8 makes a best-effort attempt to recover from stack space exhaustion with a catchable error, which frameworks have come to rely on for service availability," Node.js's
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: PLUGGYAPE Malware Uses Signal and WhatsApp to Target Ukrainian Defense Forces
item.description: The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) has disclosed details of new cyber attacks targeting its defense forces with malware known as PLUGGYAPE between October and December 2025. The activity has been attributed with medium confidence to a Russian hacking group tracked as Void Blizzard (aka Laundry Bear or UAC-0190). The threat actor is believed to be active since at least
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Taiwan Endures Greater Cyber Pressure From China
item.description: Chinese cyberattacks on Taiwan's critical infrastructure — including energy utilities and hospitals — rose 6% in 2025, averaging 2.63 million attacks a day.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Patch Tuesday, January 2026 Edition
item.description: Microsoft today issued patches to plug at least 113 security holes in its various Windows operating systems and supported software. Eight of the vulnerabilities earned Microsoft's most-dire "critical" rating, and the company warns that attackers are already exploiting one of the bugs fixed today.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: CrowdStrike to Buy Seraphic Security in Bid to Boost Browser Security
item.description: The browser protection and detection technology will be integrated into CrowdStrike's Falcon platform to protect endpoints, browser sessions, and cloud applications.
item.dc:creator: Fahmida Y. Rashid

item.title: CISO Succession Crisis Highlights How Turnover Amplifies Security Risks
item.description: When cybersecurity leadership turns over too fast, risk does not reset. It compounds.
item.dc:creator: Joan Goodchild

item.title: 'Most Severe AI Vulnerability to Date' Hits ServiceNow
item.description: The ITSM giant tacked agentic AI onto a largely unguarded legacy chatbot, exposing customers' data and connected systems.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Microsoft Starts 2026 With a Bang: A Freshly Exploited Zero-Day
item.description: The vendor's first Patch Tuesday of the year also contains fixes for 112 CVEs, nearly double the amount from last month.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: 2026 PCI SSC Training Schedule Announced
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: Shadow#Reactor Uses Text Files to Deliver Remcos RAT
item.description: Attackers use a sophisticated delivery mechanism of text-only files for RAT deployment, showcasing a clever way to bypass defensive tools and rely on the target's own utilities.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Long-Running Web Skimming Campaign Steals Credit Cards From Online Checkout Pages
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a major web skimming campaign that has been active since January 2022, targeting several major payment networks like American Express, Diners Club, Discover, JCB Co., Ltd., Mastercard, and UnionPay. "Enterprise organizations that are clients of these payment providers are the most likely to be impacted," Silent Push said in a report published today.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Malicious Chrome Extension Steals MEXC API Keys by Masquerading as Trading Tool
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a malicious Google Chrome extension that's capable of stealing API keys associated with MEXC, a centralized cryptocurrency exchange (CEX) available in over 170 countries, while masquerading as a tool to automate trading on the platform. The extension, named MEXC API Automator (ID: pppdfgkfdemgfknfnhpkibbkabhghhfh), has 29 downloads and is still
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI-Powered Crypto Scams Drive Record $17B Losses in 2025
item.description: <p>Research by Chainalysis reveals that AI-powered impersonation tactics have exploded by an unprecedented 1,400% year-over-year.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-2025-crypto-scam-losses/">AI-Powered Crypto Scams Drive Record $17B Losses in 2025</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: AsyncRAT Malware Infests Orgs via Python &amp; Cloudflare
item.description: The phishing campaign shows how attackers continue to weaponize legitimate cloud services and open source tools to evade detection and gain trust.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: [Webinar] Securing Agentic AI: From MCPs and Tool Access to Shadow API Key Sprawl
item.description: AI agents are no longer just writing code. They are executing it. Tools like Copilot, Claude Code, and Codex can now build, test, and deploy software end-to-end in minutes. That speed is reshaping engineering—but it’s also creating a security gap most teams don’t see until something breaks. Behind every agentic workflow sits a layer few organizations are actively securing: Machine Control
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: 1980s Hacker Manifesto
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: New Advanced Linux VoidLink Malware Targets Cloud and container Environments
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a previously undocumented and feature-rich malware framework codenamed VoidLink that's specifically designed for long-term, stealthy access to Linux-based cloud environments According to a new report from Check Point Research, the cloud-native Linux malware framework comprises an array of custom loaders, implants, rootkits, and modular
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: What Should We Learn From How Attackers Leveraged AI in 2025?
item.description: Old Playbook, New Scale: While defenders are chasing trends, attackers are optimizing the basics The security industry loves talking about "new" threats. AI-powered attacks. Quantum-resistant encryption. Zero-trust architectures. But looking around, it seems like the most effective attacks in 2025 are pretty much the same as they were in 2015. Attackers are exploiting the same entry points that
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ServiceNow Patches Critical AI Platform Flaw Allowing Unauthenticated User Impersonation
item.description: ServiceNow has disclosed details of a now-patched critical security flaw impacting its ServiceNow artificial intelligence (AI) Platform that could enable an unauthenticated user to impersonate another user and perform arbitrary actions as that user. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-12420, carries a CVSS score of 9.3 out of 10.0. It has been codenamed BodySnatcher by AppOmni. "This issue [.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Your personal information is on the dark web. What happens next?
item.description: If your data is on the dark web, it’s probably only a matter of time before it’s abused for fraud or account hijacking. Here’s what to do.

item.title: New Malware Campaign Delivers Remcos RAT Through Multi-Stage Windows Attack
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new campaign dubbed SHADOW#REACTOR that employs an evasive multi-stage attack chain to deliver a commercially available remote administration tool called Remcos RAT and establish persistent, covert remote access. "The infection chain follows a tightly orchestrated execution path: an obfuscated VBS launcher executed via wscript.exe invokes a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Betterment Customer Data Exposed in Crypto Scam Hack
item.description: <p>The breach occurred through a compromised third-party marketing platform, allowing attackers to impersonate the trusted financial service.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-betterment-crypto-scam-hack/">Betterment Customer Data Exposed in Crypto Scam Hack</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: CISA Warns of Active Exploitation of Gogs Vulnerability Enabling Code Execution
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has warned of active exploitation of a high-severity security flaw impacting Gogs by adding it to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-8110 (CVSS score: 8.7), relates to a case of path traversal in the repository file editor that could result in code execution. "Gogs Path
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: BreachForums Breached, Exposing 324K Cybercriminals
item.description: A massive data dump reveals real identities and details of administrators and members of the notorious hacker forum.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Multipurpose GoBruteforcer Botnet Targets 50K+ Linux Servers
item.description: Researchers detailed a souped-up version of the GoBruteforcer botnet that preys on servers with weak credentials and AI-generated configurations.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Navigating Privacy and Cybersecurity Laws in 2026 Will Prove Difficult
item.description: No matter what new laws or regulations make the cut for 2026, it's clear that compliance challenges will persist and federal legislation will be limited.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: FBI Flags Quishing Attacks From North Korean APT
item.description: A state-sponsored threat group tracked as &quot;Kimsuky&quot; sent QR-code-filled phishing emails to US and foreign government agencies, NGOs, and academic institutions.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Hexnode Moves into Endpoint Security With Hexnode XDR
n8n Supply Chain Attack Abuses Community Nodes to Steal OAuth Tokens
item.description: Threat actors have been observed uploading a set of eight packages on the npm registry that masqueraded as integrations targeting the n8n workflow automation platform to steal developers' OAuth credentials. One such package, named "n8n-nodes-hfgjf-irtuinvcm-lasdqewriit," mimics a Google Ads integration, and prompts users to link their advertising account in a seemingly legitimate form and then
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Spotlight On: Reflectiz, a New Principal Participating Organization
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: 2 Separate Campaigns Probe Corporate LLMs for Secrets
item.description: A total of 91,403 sessions targeted public LLM endpoints to find leaks in organizations' use of AI and map an expanding attack surface.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: AI Automation Exploits, Telecom Espionage, Prompt Poaching & More
item.description: This week made one thing clear: small oversights can spiral fast. Tools meant to save time and reduce friction turned into easy entry points once basic safeguards were ignored. Attackers didn’t need novel tricks. They used what was already exposed and moved in without resistance. Scale amplified the damage. A single weak configuration rippled out to millions. A repeatable flaw worked again and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Israeli Cybersecurity Startup Torq Gets $140M Funding to Hit $1.2B Valuation
item.description: <p>This latest funding brings Torq's total raised capital to $332 million, and it has plans to hire an additional 200 employees in 2026.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-torq-funding/">Israeli Cybersecurity Startup Torq Gets $140M Funding to Hit $1.2B Valuation</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Corrupting LLMs Through Weird Generalizations
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: GoBruteforcer Botnet Targets Crypto Project Databases by Exploiting Weak Credentials
item.description: A new wave of GoBruteforcer attacks has targeted databases of cryptocurrency and blockchain projects to co-opt them into a botnet that's capable of brute-forcing user passwords for services such as FTP, MySQL, PostgreSQL, and phpMyAdmin on Linux servers. "The current wave of campaigns is driven by two factors: the mass reuse of AI-generated server deployment examples that propagate common
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Meta Calls for Calm Amidst Instagram Password Reset Panic
item.description: <p>Meta stated that there had been no breach of its systems and that Instagram accounts remained secure.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-instagram-password-reset-panic/">Meta Calls for Calm Amidst Instagram Password Reset Panic</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Anthropic Launches Claude AI for Healthcare with Secure Health Record Access
item.description: Anthropic has become the latest Artificial intelligence (AI) company to announce a new suite of features that allows users of its Claude platform to better understand their health information. Under an initiative called Claude for Healthcare, the company said U.S. subscribers of Claude Pro and Max plans can opt to give Claude secure access to their lab results and health records by connecting to
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Researchers Uncover Service Providers Fueling Industrial-Scale Pig Butchering Fraud
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have shed light on two service providers that supply online criminal networks with the necessary tools and infrastructure to fuel the pig butchering-as-a-service (PBaaS) economy. At least since 2016, Chinese-speaking criminal groups have erected industrial-scale scam centers across Southeast Asia, creating special economic zones that are devoted to fraudulent investment
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: MuddyWater Launches RustyWater RAT via Spear-Phishing Across Middle East Sectors
item.description: The Iranian threat actor known as MuddyWater has been attributed to a spear-phishing campaign targeting diplomatic, maritime, financial, and telecom entities in the Middle East with a Rust-based implant codenamed RustyWater. "The campaign uses icon spoofing and malicious Word documents to deliver Rust based implants capable of asynchronous C2, anti-analysis, registry persistence, and modular
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Europol Arrests 34 Black Axe Members in Spain Over €5.9M Fraud and Organized Crime
item.description: Europol on Friday announced the arrest of 34 individuals in Spain who are alleged to be part of an international criminal organization called Black Axe. As part of an operation conducted by the Spanish National Police, in coordination with the Bavarian State Criminal Police Office and Europol, 28 arrests were made in Seville, along with three others in Madrid, two in Málaga, and one in Barcelona
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
